block.p: The Race for the Triple Crown
Horses, High Stakes, and Eternal Hope.
The Race for the Triple Crown
Horses, High Stakes, and Eternal Hope.

Ever since Sir Barton became the first horse to win it in 1919, the Triple Crown has been thrilling racing fans with dramatic achievements and unpredictable finishes. Bargain-basement champions like Seattle Slew have captured it, but it has eluded some of the greats, like Man o' War. So it seems odd that Joe Drape, a sportswriter at The New York Times, would choose to focus his book, ''The Race for the Triple Crown,'' on a single year, 2000, in which nothing really happened. There was a phenomenal horse, Fusaichi Pegasus, the brilliant, gorgeous colt that fetched $4 million at Keeneland in 1998. The first Saturday in May, FuPeg wowed spectators as he galloped from the back of the pack to win the Kentucky Derby in one of the fastest times in the race's history. But two weeks later, he lost the Preakness to Red Bullet, extinguishing all hopes for a Triple Crown. With the Belmont reduced to an anticlimax, Drape's primary subject becomes the racing scene -- the trainers, owners, jockeys and bettors. Profiling the top trainers -- like D. Wayne Lukas or Bob Baffert -- he glosses over their unsportsmanlike rivalries. Some passages are cluttered with excess detail, but Drape, who paid for his wife's engagement ring by winning a trifecta bet, writes poignantly of his personal ties to racing -- of his mother, who always bet on the gray, and his own quarter horse, Oh Desperado, who made it to the winner's circle.
